title: I get that Taliyah originally had a lockout on her W.
body:
I don't get why it was removed.

If I understand it correctly, Taliyah's W originally had a lockout animation because you needed to input the command twice - once to activate the ability, and another time to choose a direction. The lockout animation mainly existed for functional reasons.

After they changed the input to vector casting, the lockout animation technically wasn't functionally necessary because the spell now only required one input instead of two to make it work. So they removed the lockout. Apparently this also made the spell "feel better" at the cost of some game health, since this opened up the possibility for W->E combos when previously only E->W was possible.

I personally don't understand why the spell couldn't keep its lockout animation after a completed input. I feel like it's much healthier for the game and her kit. Other abilities have long lockout animations without "feeling bad", such as Lux R, Ezreal R, Orianna R, Braum R, etc. The return of W's lockout animation would encourage Taliyah's zoning potential more than her burst potential by removing the guaranteed E after a successful W hit, which would open up her kit to be more balanceable.

TL;DR I think it is completely feasible for Taliyah's current vector cast W to have a lockout animation post-cast and remain viable, which would make her much easier to balance overall.

Thoughts?

To be realistic, Lockout was there for a reason. It was the reason why she was so unique and had a kit that allowed offensive and defensive zone control that punished gapclosing-happy players severely.

Ever since it was removed, her entire kit fell apart because by the nature of her W and E. Those two skills were balanced around Lockout. E was allowed to heavily burst people regardless of HP and resistances because it was situational. She couldn't perform W into E, so she had to go into a close range. Allowing her to use W into E made the setup too safe and E's damage had to be lowered to almost nothing. Of course, using E into W was affected and there is basically no point in using it anymore, getting rid of {{champion:163}}'s "Zoning" aspect. E is usually used as a tacked on DPS skill when W is used first. 

Basically, her skill floor and skill ceiling completely fell into the ground because the mechanic that made her so challenging got removed. Everything rewarding that came with overcoming that challenge was dumbed down and we basically have this zone control mage who can only zone through a giant wall that is up every minute and a half at max level. I'd take {{champion:61}} or {{champion:112}} over her any day.

Exactly!! E feels more like an extension of W as it is now, rather than a spell that ought to be powerful on its own.

I actually welcomed the vector cast change, since to me it's more intuitive. I think of the vector cast as a directional arrow, rather than a line on the ground. Makes sense to me, at least.

I'm not in favor of the lockout removal, though. It takes expression of skill out of her kit and allows the W->E combo to unintentionally consume a lot of her power budget.

I think there's a world where Taliyah's W can exist as a vector cast, locked out spell post-input.

Vector cast is for abilities which need to be dragged out themselves.
Aka, Viktor's laser or Rumble's ultimate field.

The old method that was on Taliyah's worked fine. Click once to set the cast location, click in a direction to set the direction it would push. Forgo the second click to have it knock vertically up.
Viktor's laser and Rumble's ultimate field are always the same length, regardless of how long the vector is drawn out. The vector cast is simply a way of giving a direction to the spell.

Vector casting adds a delay though, and unlike someone like Viktor who pretty much just uses his laser for farming or on CC'd targets, and Rumble's ult being an ult as well as massive in size, someone like Taliyah who has an absolutely time-placement critical ability like her W, is ruined by the delay. Yes, said delay is around 0.25-5 seconds. That might seem small in general, but to a kit like hers, that's a huge added delay. In addition, vector casting means she is forced into picking a direction at the start unlike the old version, where she had the 1s after the first click to pick a direction, meaning she had no delay and could adapt slightly if needed within up to the 1s until at which point the second cast (knock/push) would trigger.
Well like I've said somewhere else, they can always increase the size of the W area if they feel like that's necessary. I wouldn't do that though unless ABSOLUTELY necessary.
A better change would be making the 1s timer (from cast to actual knock) start the moment the first click is made, instead of waiting until the mouse finishes dragging and lets go.
That's asking to have the W change essentially reverted.

Not really?
It's still click-and-drag like people who had near no experience with her preferred since it's more intuitive and takes less intelligence to learn, as opposed to click-move mouse-click.
It just removes the problematic and unreasonable delay with vector casting.

It would be two inputs though - the initial click which initiates the spell, and the release which indicates a direction.

I honestly can't think of another spell that works this way. I'm not sure if the coding exists in the game for that. And if it does, it could mess with normal casting vs. quick casting, quick casting with indicators, etc.

Basically, it could POSSIBLY be done, but I don't think it's as simple as "do this ez pz".

Oh, inplane reminded me of something.

The difference between Rumble/Viktor's vector casting and Taliyah's is their abilities are usually used entirely separately. They just use it and done.
Taliyah has to combo it extremely quickly with her E to get any actual meaningful result, where the drag and delay feels awful now to do with vector casting as E-W instead, since the change was meant to promote W-E which really shouldn't have been ever possible.
But they decided to make it possible to make Taliyah easier to play instead of taking skill and smarts to play.
So as a result, they had to nerf the incredible damage on her E-W combo since any half braindead monkey could do W-E for same damage now.
To be fair, the W change wasn't meant to promote the W->E combo. It was meant to promote more easily accessible use of W. The W->E combo was an unfortunate, but known, side effect of the change.

vectorcast is not needed for abillitys 'which need to be dragged out themselves'
It is needed for abillitys that need not only a cast point, but also an direction(vector)

And thalia's W is prettymuch that, an spell that not only requires the information of an cast-point, but can also use directional information in form of a vector.

Now the difference is that victor and rumbel **need** the vector, thalia **can use** the vector but theoretically funktions without.

As a result, it's quite questionable that thalia's W starts at the end of the command chain rather than after the first click, which technically would be very well possible.
The very idea of vectorcasteing for her W is fitting and natural, it's just the implementation that failed, becasue riot is stubborn and thinks vectorcasteing has to be **exactly** like victors E, just copy pasta the code, instead of maybe considering that a delayed groundtargeted aoe is a bit different from an instant line skillshot and thus might need some adjustments to the casting paradigm.

Here's why I originally put a spell cast lockout on Taliyah's W:

* I wanted to give the player breathing room to press the W button a second time.
* I was very scared of W into E as a best case burst scenario

Here's why we reached the decision to remove the lockout:

* It felt really awful not to be able to cast anything else if you got the W combo down quickly. It felt like you got better at W (you're quicker now) but the game won't let you use that hard-won skill
* It turns out that we can either have proper spell queueing during a delay or good communication that a spell cannot currently be cast, but not both. This is one of the areas in the game we're working to improve. Either way, the experience was not up to our standards.

It also turns out that I was wrong to be scared of W into E. Ranges and cooldowns make this combo reasonably balanced. 

The things we're struggling with right now on her kit are her wave clear (which we've hit very hard. It was meant to be a strength, but it was clearly excessive), the difference is usefulness of her ult between coordinated and uncoordinated play (we always knew this was going to be trouble but signed ourselves up for it because the skill is cool), and how much she falls off late game. Her theoretical DPS is absurdly high, but the later the game goes, the more of a premium there is on getting your damage out INSTANTLY, and her Q means she always has to wait a minimum of 2s to get one rotation out. Again, if you do the math? Her late game DPS is off the charts: At 40% CDR, she has a 2.4s CD spell that deals 420 + 1.2 AP. That's just the one spell.  But then you look at actual data and we see there are very few champions in the game who fall off late game quite as hard as she does. 

Remember that ours is a game that's never done. Obviously we'll continue working on her and we'll get her into a good spot.

The issue is the vector casting method implemented removed her vertical knockup as well as forced a ridiculous, inherent human-based delay into the combo, because the ability won't start until you finish dragging and let go.

The old cast let you knock straight up as well as always, ALWAYS, starting 1s after the very first click of placement for the W itself, whether or not you input any directions or commands after it. There was no possible extraneous delay.

Correct, I think W->E is too strong and consumes a lot of her power budget. However, I still think E->W SHOULD be strong, since it takes forethought to set up. Hence having a lockout on W.

As a control mage, Taliyah's strength shouldn't be in her reliable burst, but rather in her zones of potential burst. I think there's no doubt in anyone's mind that E->W takes more skill than W->E, since casting E doesn't guarantee a successful W, but a successful W guarantees hitting E. Unreliability can allow room for the combo to potentially hit harder and make it more threatening as a zone Taliyah can control without making the combo consume so much of her power budget, as it does now. 

Edit: Hitting the combo should feel rewarding, so *nerfing* the damage is counterproductive. I'd rather they make the combo unreliable so that they can make the combo hit hard and feel rewarding. Currently, the combo has already been nerfed because its reliability was upped. Taliyah isn't supposed to be a burst mage, so imo she shouldn't have a reliable burst combo. Should she have an incredibly powerful zone that can burst squishies? Absolutely. Should it be reliable? Probably not.

Edit2: Corrected "nerfing" (from "needing").

I get what you are saying about how unreliability can allow her to potentially hit harder, and I understand why you think E>W is a more skillful combo. However, I think that Taliyah actually does need reliable burst.

The first thing I want to point out is that, while W>E is far more reliable than E>W was, Taliyah's burst is still nowhere near as reliable as similar champions. If you look at her like a control mage, W is far easier to dodge than something like an Anivia walking up, placing her ult under you, and forcing you to eat a double damage point-and-click E. If you look at her in the vein of a champion like Twisted Fate or Ahri (I think Taliyah is much more similar to these two heavy roamers than she is to a traditonal control mage), W>E is much easier to dodge than point blank Ahri Charms or the targetted Gold Card.

Now that I've established that her burst is nowhere near as reliable as comparable champions, let me elaborate on why Taliyah's burst needs to be strong. With a passive and ultimate that are 100% dedicated to roaming, and only one form of hard CC, Taliyah needs some way to contribute to normal teamfights. Q has minimal AoE and is weak if you aren't consistently moving around, so the W>E combo needs to provide very strong AoE damage.

They could always front load E damage into its initial proc. That makes it more potent as an AoE spell since its area is actually rather large.

Also, the detonation damage only affects the champion that detonates it, so knocking more than one person into the field doesn't increase its AoE damage.

I get what you're saying, but I'm still not convinced that Taliyah should have reliable burst. I definitely think she needs burst in some way, but that can be accomplished in other ways that are more healthy than a guaranteed E after W hit. They could even compensate this change by making the W a tiny bit bigger, but that's an extreme measure imo.
